Anaerobic conversion of methane to acetonitrile over solid-state-pyrolysis-synthesized GaN catalysts Korawich Trangwachirachai Investigation Formal analysis Validation Writing – original draft Chin-Han Chen Investigation Formal analysis Validation Yu-Chuan Lin Supervision Project administration ⁎ Department of Chemical Engineering, National Cheng Kung University, No. 1 University Rd., Tainan 70101, Taiwan Department of Chemical Engineering National Cheng Kung University No. 1 University Rd. Tainan 70101 Taiwan Department of Chemical Engineering, National Cheng Kung University, No. 1 University Rd., Tainan 70101, Taiwan ⁎ Corresponding author. The anaerobic conversion of methane to acetonitrile (AcCN) using GaN catalysts synthesized through the solid-state pyrolysis of gallium nitrate hydrate and melamine was investigated. A series of GaN catalysts (unsupported GaN, 50 wt% GaN/SiO2, and 5 wt% GaN/SiO2) were prepared, and their physicochemical properties were analyzed. The as-synthesized GaN catalysts had higher porosities, lower crystallinities, and better activities than those of the commercial GaN. Among tested catalysts, 5 wt% GaN/SiO2 displayed the highest methane conversion rate and AcCN productivity at 700 °C. Residual carbonaceous and nitrogen species, such as sp2-N (N = C) and cyano-N (NC), are likely to participate in the transformation of methane to AcCN. The activity of post-reaction 5 wt% GaN/SiO2 could be partially rejuvenated by a calcination-nitridation-activation process. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Acetonitrile Gallium nitride Methane Nitrogen 1 Introduction Acetonitrile (AcCN) is a valuable chemical being used as an electrolyte, solvent, and platform chemical [1,2]. AcCN is a byproduct of the Sohio process for acrylonitrile production, accounting for approximately 4% yield [1,2]. However, a low productivity does not match the increasing demand for AcCN. The global market of AcCN approached 122 kilotonne in 2020 with an expected 5% growth rate before 2026 [3]. Therefore, it is necessary to develop new methods for AcCN production. The growing demand for AcCN has stimulated various studies on catalysis research. Ayari et al. [4] used Cr-ZSM-5 catalysts for the conversion of ethylene to AcCN, and reported a high yield of AcCN (approximately 23%) at 500 °C. Zhang et al. [5] reported a 41% yield of AcCN derived from glycerol amination using Fe19.2K0.2/γ-Al2O3. Ishida et al. [6] studied the ammoxidation of primary alcohols to nitriles using MnO2, Co3O4, and NiO. They claimed that amines are intermediates in the formation of nitriles. Tseng et al. [7] investigated the conversion of primary and secondary amines to the corresponding nitriles over an amide-derived NNN-Ru (II) hydride complex in oxygen-free environments. The presence of H2 negatively affected the amine dehydrogenation due to enhanced nitrile hydrogenation. Table S1 presents the existing processes of AcCN production. Earlier studies have provided alternative routes for AcCN production. Nevertheless, limited feedstocks can hurdle the aforementioned developments. For example, ethylamine is prepared from ethanol amination [8], and the production of ethanol demands arable land for the cultivation of industrial crops. Methane, the main component in natural gas and biogas, is the most abundant resource being used for heat and electricity generation. The catalytic conversion of methane to valuable chemicals shall increase the atom efficiency of methane [9]. The non-oxidative conversion of methane to higher C-containing products has been the “holy grail” in the catalysis society [10,11]. The rigid structure of methane is due to its formidable dissociation energy of the CH bond (439.3 kJ mol−1) [12]. Transition metal nitrides (TMNs)-based catalysts are promising for various reactions, particularly nitrogen transfer reactions [13–15]. Hosono et al. [16] reported several nitride-based catalysts for ammonia synthesis, with CeN being the most active. TMN catalysts, especially Mo-based nitrides, have also been used in ammonia decomposition [15]. Srifa et al. [17] studied ammonia decomposition over a series of Mo-based nitrides promoted by Fe, Co, and Ni. They revealed that the binary nitrides were more active than the monometallic nitrides, and Co3Mo3N had the highest ammonia decomposition rate. Recent studies have reported that methane can be activated by GaN [18–22]. GaN catalyzed methane conversion to hydrocarbons was reviewed by Galadima and Muraza [23]. The Kopyscinski group [19–22] found that pristine GaN and GaN/SBA-15 can transform methane to ethylene at temperatures above 650 °C. Considerable methane conversion (∼5%) and ethylene selectivity (71%) at the outset were obtained with a low coke yield (27%). However, severe GaN synthesis conditions (nitridation of Ga2O3 in a 99% NH3 stream at above 700 °C for 9 h) remain challenging. Zhang et al. [24] investigated the facile synthesis of GaN using a solid-phase reaction. The obtained GaN catalyst was highly active for the oxidative dehydrogenation of propane in CO2. Accordingly, GaN is active in the CH activation of light alkanes. To the best of our knowledge, the catalytic conversion of methane to AcCN has not yet been published. Herein, we investigated the anaerobic conversion of methane to AcCN using GaN-based catalysts. A simplified route of methane conversion to AcCN over solid-state-synthesized GaN (ss-GaN) catalyst is shown in Scheme 1. The ss-GaN catalysts exhibited desirable methane conversion (3%−9%) and AcCN productivity (326 µmol/gGa/min) at the outset of the reaction. Moreover, residual sp2-N (N = C) and cyano-N (NC) species developed by the solid-state pyrolysis of gallium nitrate hydrate and melamine were discovered to participate in AcCN formation. A plausible mechanism for AcCN formation was thereby proposed. Furthermore, a calcination-nitridation-activation procedure for catalyst regeneration was tested. This study seems to be ushered in a new route for upgrading methane to valuable chemicals. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials All chemicals were used as received. Gallium (III) nitrate hydrate (Ga(NO3)3•xH2O, 99.9998%) was purchased from Acros. Melamine (C3H6N6, 99%), silicon oxide (SiO2, high surface area, 3.18 mm pellets), and commercial GaN (99.99%, denoted as com-GaN) were purchased from Alfa Aesar. SiO2 was ground into fine particles before being used as the support. 2.2 Synthesis of GaN and GaN/SiO2 GaN was synthesized using a modified solid-state pyrolysis method [24]. First, a mixture of gallium nitrate hydrate and melamine (1:1 by weight) in methanol (20 mL) was ultrasonicated for 15 min and then dried in an oven at 90 °C for 10 h. Then, the dried powder was transferred to a horizontal quartz tube and pyrolyzed at 800 °C (1.5 °C/min) for 1 h under a flow of N2 (20 mL/min). The obtained yellowish-brown powder was denoted as ss-GaN. For the synthesis of silica-supported GaN catalysts, the same procedure of ss-GaN preparation was used, and SiO2 was added during the sonication step. The obtained pale-yellow powder was denoted as xGaN/SiO2 (x is the designated weight loading of Ga, namely, 5 wt% and 50 wt%). All catalysts were sieved and crushed into particles in the range of 40–80 mesh. 2.3 Catalyst characterizations Powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns were recorded using a diffractometer (Rigaku D/Max-IIB) at 40 kV and 40 mA with Ni-filtered Cu Kα (λ=1.5406 Å) radiation. An inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometer (ICP-MS, THERMO-ELEMENT XR) was used to quantify the gallium composition and an elemental analyzer (EA, German elementar, UNICUBE) was utilized to measure the nitrogen contents. N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms were obtained using an automated N2 physisorption analyzer (ASAP 2020 Plus, Micromeritics). The Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) method in the relative pressure range of 0.01–0.1 was used to estimate the surface area (SBET) Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) and differential thermal analysis (DTA) were performed using a TA Q600. The X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) spectrum was measured using a PHI 5000 VersaProbe spectrometer equipped with a monochromatized aluminum source with a wavelength of 1486.6 eV. The C 1 s binding energy of adventitious carbon at 285.0 eV was used to calibrate the energy shift. Fourier-transform infrared (FTIR) spectra were recorded using a Thermo Scientific Nicolet iS50 spectrometer. A diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier transform spectroscopy (DRIFTS) cell (Praying Mantis, Harrick Scientific) was used for the in-situ IR analysis. Two sets of in-situ analyses were performed in N2 (20 mL/min) and in 50% CH4/N2 (20 mL/min) streams. The IR background was collected at room temperature. The cell was then heated to 100, 200, 300, 400, 500, 600, and 700 °C. Each temperature was kept isothermal for 5 min and then cooled to room temperature to record the spectra. The effect of reaction time was also studied by holding the temperature at 700 °C for 1 or 3 h. X-ray absorption spectra (XAS) at Ga K-edge were recorded in transmission mode at the beamline TLS-17C1 of the National Synchrotron Radiation Research Center, Taiwan. The electron storage ring was operated at 1.5 GeV with a beam current of 360 mA under top-up injection. A double-crystal Si(111) monochromator was employed for energy scanning. The incident and transmitted beam intensities were measured using gas-filled ionization chambers. A reference Ga2O3 powder was simultaneously recorded using a third ionization chamber for energy calibration. All XAS data were collected at ambient temperature. X-ray absorption near edge structure (XANES) at N K-edge were performed at the high-energy spherical grating monochromator (HSGM) TLS-20A (NSRRC) beamline using the total electron yield (TEY) mode with a base pressure of 5 × 10−9 Torr and a resolving power of about E/DE = 8000. The commercial GaN was used for energy calibration. The Athena and Artemis software version 0.9.26 included in the Demeter package [25] were used to analyze the data. 2.4 Activity evaluation To select an appropriate operating temperature for methane conversion to AcCN, temperature-programmed surface reaction (TPSR) analysis was conducted using a horizontal fixed-bed reactor. Approximately 0.2 g of 5GaN/SiO2 was placed into a quartz tube (13 mm OD x 10 mm ID x 220 mm long) and treated in a N2 stream (20 mL/min) at 700 °C (10 °C/min) for 30 min. After cooling to 500 °C in the same stream, methane was fed (10 mL/min), and the temperature was ramped linearly to 800 °C (10 °C/min). Downstream products were analyzed using a mass spectrometer (MS, Thermostar GSD 320, Pfeiffer Vacuum). Activity evaluation was performed using the same fixed-bed reactor. Approximately 0.2 g of catalyst was sandwiched in the middle of the tube by quartz wool. The catalyst was pretreated at 700 °C (10 °C/min) for 30 min under a flow of N2 (20 mL/min). After catalyst activation, a methane (99.99%v/v) flow of 10 mL/min (gas hourly space velocity = 3000 m L C H 4 /g/h) was introduced into the system for the activity test. All tubing of the reaction system was electrically heated at 150 °C to avoid condensation of the products. The products were analyzed using an on-line gas chromatograph (GC) with a flame ionization detector, a thermal conductivity detector, and a quadrupole MS. Methane conversion, conversion rate, and productivity were calculated using the following equations: (1) CH 4 conversion ( % ) = ∑ [ ( C atoms in the product ) x C x H y ] CH 4 , inlet x 100 (2) CH 4 conversion rate ( μ mol / g Ga / min ) = % CH 4 conversion x CH 4 , inlet Ga weight in the catalyst bed (3) Productivity ( μ mol / g Ga / min ) = ( C atoms in the product ) x C x H y Ga weight in the catalyst bed Where CH4, inlet is the molar flow rate of methane (µmol/min) at the inlet and CxHy is the molar flow rate of the products (µmol/min) at the outlet. The CH4 conversion means the transformation of carbon (percentage,%) to detectable products. The conversion may be underestimated because deposited coke was excluded in the detectable products. 2.5 Hydrogen co-feeding and catalyst regeneration Hydrogen co-feeding experiment was conducted in the same fixed-bed reactor using the same amount of catalyst and pretreatment procedure as mentioned above. The methane flow rate was maintained at 10 mL/min, and the concentration of methane was fixed at 50% v/v, balancing with a mixed hydrogen and nitrogen stream (10 mL/min). The fractions of H2 and N2 were set at 0 (pure N2), 0.25 (25% H2/N2), 0.50 (50% H2/N2), or 1.00 (pure H2) to determine the effect of hydrogen concentration on the distributions of hydrogen cyanide (HCN) and AcCN. Catalyst regeneration was performed using a calcination-nitridation-activation process. After a 6-h test, the temperature was cooled to 600 °C (30 min) under a flow of N2 (20 mL/min) and kept isothermal for 3 h under a flow of air (25 mL/min) to remove deposited coke. The temperature was then raised to 800 °C (30 min) under a flow of N2 (20 mL/min). After flushing for 30 min, the N2 flow was switched to a 10% NH3/He stream (20 mL/min) and kept isothermal for 9 h for catalyst nitridation. After nitridation, the system was cooled to room temperature in the same stream. The catalytic performance of the regenerated catalyst was then evaluated after subjecting to the same activation step as its fresh form. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Methane conversion over supported GaN catalysts The TPSR experiment was conducted to evaluate a proper temperature for methane conversion, see Fig. 1 . The increased methane signal (m/z = 16) in 600–690 °C was attributed to the decomposition of residual carbonaceous species after co-pyrolysis of the mixture of gallium nitrate hydrate and melamine. At temperatures higher than 690 °C, a downward trend of methane signal accompanying an upward trend of H2 signal was observed, suggesting that the conversion of methane was enhanced. The C2 products (ethylene and ethane, m/z = 28) showed two peaks at 700 and 750 °C. By considering the signals of m/z = 12 and 14 (not shown), the peak at 700 °C was attributed to desorbed nitrogen, and the peak at 750 °C was related to desorbed C2 products. The onsets of HCN (m/z = 27) and AcCN (m/z = 41) were at approximately 650 and 620 °C, respectively. AcCN displayed a broad peak in 650–750 °C while HCN showed a peak at 750 °C. The signal of benzene (m/z = 78) was detected at temperatures higher than 750 °C. Accordingly, an activity evaluation was conducted at 700 °C to maximize AcCN productivity. Fig. 2 shows the time course of methane conversion, conversion rate, and productivity of the tested catalysts at 700 °C. The initial methane conversion (Fig. 2a) exhibited an increasing trend with respect to the Ga loading following the order of 3.6% (5GaN/SiO2) < 4.1% (50GaN/SiO2) < 8.8% (ss-GaN). The conversion declined gradually and then leveled off at approximately 1% for a 6 h duration. The decreasing trend of methane conversion indicates catalyst deactivation, possibly caused by coke deposition. The com-GaN showed negligible methane conversion (∼0.5%). Fig. 2b shows the conversion rates of the tested catalysts. The onset value of conversion rate increased following an ascending order as 4.1 µmol/gGa/min (com-GaN) < 46.6 µmol/gGa/min (ss-GaN) < 69.7 µmol/gGa/min (50GaN/SiO2) < 372.4 µmol/gGa/min (5GaN/SiO2). C2, HCN, and AcCN were the main products with trace amounts of aromatics (Fig. 2c to 2f). A gradually decreasing trend with respect to the operating time was observed for each product. The time-course of the productivity, excluding aromatics, showed a decreasing trend in the order of 5GaN/SiO2 > 50GaN/SiO2 > ss-GaN > com-GaN. The reproducibility test was done over three different batches of 5GaN/SiO2 catalyst, see Figure S1. The 95% confidence interval for each data point was less than 6%, indicating that the reproducibility of our catalytic system is acceptable. The accumulated coke in the post-reaction catalyst was measured using TGA/DTA (Figure S2). All samples exhibited a weight increase accompanying with exothermic heat flow at temperatures higher than 650 °C. This indicates that GaN can be oxidized to Ga2O3 at above 650 °C [19,24]. The weight increase and heat flow were insignificant over 5GaN/SiO2, likely due to the low Ga loading. Each fresh catalyst showed a weight loss in the range of 150–650 °C, suggesting the removal of carbonaceous species [24]. For spent catalyst, an additional weight loss at 450–600 °C was observed, indicating the burning of deposited coke. The amount of deposited coke increased with respect to the increased Ga loading as 1.2 mg/ g cat < (com-GaN) < 2.0 mg/gcat (5GaN/SiO2) < 5.6 mg/gcat (50GaN/SiO2) < 10.0 mg/gcat (ss-GaN). From the TGA/DTA analysis, 600 °C was selected as the calcination temperature in the catalyst regeneration step because coke can be removed with limited extent of oxidized GaN at 600 °C. In sum, the activity test showed that (i) ss-GaN had the highest methane conversion and amounts of deposited coke, (ii) 5GaN/SiO2 had the highest conversion rate and AcCN productivity, and (iii) com-GaN was nearly inactive in methane conversion. These results suggest that the activity and productivity can be correlated to the GaN crystallite size and/or its degree of amorphization. 3.2 Bulk structures of GaN catalysts The relative compositions of Ga and N were listed in Table 1 . Each catalyst had its Ga content close to its nominal value, while the N content varied. The com-GaN had its molar ratio of Ga/N of about 1.3, likely due to the presence of some impurities. Each as-prepared catalyst had its Ga/N molar ratio less than 1, indicating the presence of non-stoichiometric nitrogen. A decreasing trend of the obtained Ga/N molar ratio with respect to the Ga content was also observed. Figure S3 shows the adsorption-desorption isotherm and pore size distribution, and Table 1 presents the porosities of the tested catalysts. Each catalyst exhibited a type IV isotherm and type H1 hysteresis loop. The com-GaN had a lower surface area (4.4 m2/g) and pore volume (0.03 cm3/g) than those of ss-GaN (30.9 m2/g and 0.09 cm3/g). The difference implied that as-prepared GaN had a higher porosity. Immobilizing GaN on SiO2 can improve catalyst porosity. Besides, the lower the Ga loading, the higher the porosity can be. A possible explanation is that pore blockage of SiO2 caused by immobilizing GaN particles. Fig. 3 shows the XRD patterns of GaN-based catalysts. The diffraction peaks of com-GaN were observed at 2θ = 32.5°, 34.6°, 37.0°, 48.3°, 57.9°, 63.7°, 69.1°, and 70.8°, corresponding to the (100), (002), (101), (102), (110), (103), (112), and (201) planes of wurtzite structure GaN (PDF#74–0243) [24]. The diffraction patterns of ss-GaN and 50GaN/SiO2 were similar to that of com-GaN with weaker amplitudes, indicating the presence of smaller GaN crystallites and higher extents of amorphous phases. 5GaN/SiO2 had negligible signals at 2θ = 30°−40°, suggesting that GaN particles were too small to be detected or were not formed. The Scherrer equation was applied for crystallite size estimation using the full width at half maximum of the (101) plane [26]. The com-GaN showed the largest crystallite size (18.2 nm), followed by ss-GaN (11.4 nm) and 50GaN/SiO2 (7.6 nm). The post-reaction catalyst was also tested. The diffraction peaks of spent ss-GaN and 50GaN/SiO2 were intensified, possibly due to the agglomeration of GaN particles in methane conversion. Still, the diffractions of the spent 5GaN/SiO2 are insignificant. Fig. 4 shows the X-ray absorption near edge structure (XANES) and the radial distribution functions (RDFs) obtained from the Fourier transformation of the k 3-weighted extended X-ray absorption fine structure (EXAFS) data of fresh and spent catalysts. In the XANES spectra, eight oscillation peaks in the range of approximately 300 eV higher than the adsorption edge were identified for each GaN catalyst. The shoulder at 10,390.5 eV belonging to Ga2O3 was absent, indicating that GaN phase was dominant [27]. Although the eight oscillations of 5GaN/SiO2 were insignificant, the characteristic peak of GaN at 10,382.5 eV was identified. A possible explanation is that small GaN particles have more lattice distortion, thereby dampening its XANES profile [28]. The RDFs of all catalysts revealed two major peaks at 1.5 Å and 2.8 Å, corresponding to the 1st Ga-N and the 2nd Ga-Ga shells, respectively [27,29]. Table 2 presents the parameters obtained from the EXAFS curve fitting results. Since GaN has a wurtzite structure, the values of coordination number (CN) of the 1st Ga-N and the 2nd Ga-Ga shells are 4 and 12, respectively. The CN values of the 1st shell of fresh samples increased in the following the order: ss-GaN (2.9) < 50GaN/SiO2 (3.8) < 5GaN/SiO2 (4.5); the 2nd shell, 5GaN/SiO2 (2.8) < 50GaN/SiO2 (7.4) < ss-GaN (8.4). The former trend indicated that varying the Ga loading can change the coordination chemistry of Ga; the latter trend, GaN particle size is reduced by decreasing the Ga loading [30,31]. For each spent catalyst, the CN value of the 1st Ga-N shell was close to its fresh form, suggesting wurtzite GaN phase was intact. However, the CN value of the 2nd Ga-Ga shell of the spent catalyst was higher than that of its respective fresh form. The increased CN value of the 2nd Ga-Ga shell of spent catalyst indicated the agglomeration of GaN crystallite in methane conversion. The normalized N K-edge XANES spectra of fresh com-GaN and 5GaN/SiO2 are shown in Fig. 5 a. For com-GaN, there are four characteristic absorption features (A1, B1, C1, and D1), corresponding to the different s and p hybridized orbitals [32]. The XANES spectrum of com-GaN is in line with those reported in the previous literatures [32–34], i.e., the feature of B1 has the strongest intensity compared to those of A1 and C1 responses. These four responses were fitted using six Gaussian peaks (G1-G6) to simulate the sp3 and sp2 environments of N species. The G2, G4, and G5 are referred to the sp3 environment, while the G1, G3, and G6 are the characters of sp2 environment [32]. Thus, the peak area ratio of (G2+G4+G5)/(G1+G3+G6) can be applied for the quantitative estimation of the relative composition of sp3-to-sp2 environment (sp3/sp2), where the sp3 and sp2 environment are the N in wurtzite GaN and amorphous N species, respectively [34]. The fresh 5GaN/SiO2 shows a similar absorption profile with weaker B1 intensity compared to its own A1 and C1 features. Two absorption peaks at 399.9 and 401.6 eV were observed, which were attributed to π*CN = C and π*N-3C of amorphous nitrogen [35]. In addition, the sp3/sp2 ratio of the 5GaN/SiO2 (0.80) is smaller than that of the com-GaN (1.28). This implies that the 5GaN/SiO2 contains higher amounts of the amorphous N than that of com-GaN, as evidenced by the higher production rate of AcCN. Fig. 5b shows the N K-edge XANES spectra of post-reaction com-GaN and 5GaN/SiO2. The four characteristic absorption features of com-GaN could still be observed after a 6-h reaction test. Moreover, the sp3/sp2 environments of the fresh (1.28) and the spent com-GaN (1.33) catalysts were nearly identical. These results indicated that com-GaN has a higher crystallinity and its sp3/sp2 environments before and after reaction were nearly identical. The spectrum of the spent 5GaN/SiO2 was similar to that of com-GaN. The π*CN = C and π*N-3C responses were vanished for spent 5GaN/SiO2. Moreover, the sp3/sp2 ratio was increased from 0.80 (fresh 5GaN/SiO2) to 1.08 (post-reaction 5GaN/SiO2). Thus, the post-reaction 5GaN/SiO2 should have a higher crystallinity than its fresh form due to the consumption of amorphous N species. 3.3 Surface properties of GaN catalysts Fig. 6 shows the XPS spectra and Table 3 presents the surface compositions. Each catalyst had lower concentrations of Ga and N, and higher concentrations of C and O than their respective bulk compositions, indicating the surface enrichment of C and O of the as-prepared GaN catalysts. The XPS photolines of Ga 3d (Fig. 6a) were located at approximately 20.0 eV, which could be deconvoluted into three peaks at 20.3, 19.4, and 17.8 eV. The peak at 20.3 eV was assigned to the Ga-O bond; the peak at 19.4 eV, the Ga-N bond. Another peak at 17.8 eV was related to the N 1 s core level [36]. The O 1 s spectra of the GaN catalysts were presented in Figure S4. The broad signal can be deconvoluted into three sub-peaks for com-GaN and ss-GaN at 533.2 eV (OH), 531.8 eV (O2−), and 530.4 eV (O-Ga), respectively [37,38]. The presence of the O-Ga bond can be attributed to the incomplete conversion of mixed gallium nitrate hydrate and melamine to GaN by pyrolysis [22]. An additional peak at 532.6 eV was observed for the silica-supported GaN, which was related to the O-Si bond [39]. The N 1 s spectra of the GaN catalysts (see Fig. 6b) exhibited a broad peak in the range of 390–402 eV. The N 1 s spectrum of com-GaN was deconvoluted into 5 peaks at 399.5 eV (NH), 397.1 eV (N-Ga), 395.7 eV (Auger-Ga), 394.2 eV (Auger-Ga), and 393.0 eV (Auger-Ga) [40]. Two additional peaks at 400.6 eV (NC, cyano-N) and 398.2 eV (N = C, sp2-N) were found for each as-prepared catalyst [41,42]. These newly created nitrogen species are likely to participate in AcCN formation. Fig. 7 a shows the ratio of the NC peak area of spent and fresh GaN catalysts with respect to the Ga loading, and Fig. 7b displays the ratio of the sp2-N peak area of spent and fresh catalysts. The ratios were lower than 1, suggesting the consumption of cyano-N and sp2-N species in methane conversion. Moreover, both of the ratios showed increasing trends with increased Ga loading. These trends implied that the more the Ga loading, the lesser the extent of cyano-N and sp2-N species were consumed in methane conversion. This observation is in line with the trends of AcCN and HCN productivities (5GaN/SiO2 > 50GaN/SiO2 > ss-GaN, see Fig. 2e and 2f). Figure S5 shows the C 1 s spectra of GaN-based catalysts. The com-GaN exhibited a peak at approximately 284.5 eV, which could be deconvoluted into two sub-species at 284.6 eV (adventitious carbon) and 286.3 eV (CNHx; x = 1, 2) [41,43]. The C 1 s spectra of solid-state synthesized catalysts could be divided into four species at 284.6 eV (adventitious carbon), 285.3 eV (CN) [44], 285.7 eV (C = N) [45], and 286.3 eV (CN) [46], respectively. These two additional responses were attributed to the presence of sp2-C and cyano groups as observed in the N 1 s spectra. Fig. 8 a exhibits the FTIR spectra of fresh GaN catalysts in the range of 850–3900 cm−1 at room temperature. The com-GaN sample showed no absorption peak. In contrast, all synthesized catalysts exhibited vibration bands in the regions of 1500–1700, 2000–2300, and 3000–3600 cm−1, corresponding to the vibrations of sp2-N (N = C) [47], cyano-N group (NC) [48,49], and -NHx/-OH [49], respectively. These species were attributed to the residual C- and N-containing species of GaN made by solid-state pyrolysis. The temperature-resolved in-situ FTIR profiles of 5GaN/SiO2 (Fig. 8b) exhibited gradually decreased amplitudes in 1500–1700 cm−1 and 2000–2300 cm−1 with respect to the increase of temperature, implying the consumption of sp2-N and cyano-N species. The amplitudes of the broad peak at 3000–3600 cm−1 (-NHx) and the peak at 3491 cm−1 (-OH) [50] also decreased significantly with increasing temperature, suggesting deamination and dehydration were enhanced. An additional experiment was conducted under a flow of N2 (Figure S6) to clarify the role of the NHx and OH groups in methane conversion. The broad peak in 3000–3600 cm−1 was notably decreased without methane feeding, underlining that deamination and dehydration occurred upon heating. That is, NHx and OH groups are bystanders in methane conversion. Noting that phase transformation of cyano group was observed with elevating temperature. The peaks at 2180 and 2200 cm−1 gradually dwindled while new responses at 2230 and 2292 cm−1 were developed. It was suggested that the cyano group at a lower frequency was contributed by a conjugated double-bond from the polymeric paracyanogen-liked structure [51]. The polymeric chain can be thermally decomposed, resulting in an increased extent of terminal cyano moieties, i.e., NC groups [52,53]. Accordingly, the increase of the NC groups caused a blue-shift of the cyano group with increasing temperature. 3.4. Proposed mechanism of AcCN production Fig. 9 shows the proposed mechanism of AcCN production. Step (i) shows the wurtzite GaN with the conjugated sp2-N species. This conjugated double-bond structure could be decomposed into cyano groups (NC, step(ii)) with thermal input. Luzgin et al. [54] reported that the initial CH dissociation of methane predominantly occurs via the alkyl pathway. Therefore, the CH dissociation of methane should form a methyl and a hydrogen atom: the methyl attaches to carbon while the hydrogen attaches to the neighboring N site of the wurtzite GaN (step (iii)), forming CH3CN species. Subsequently, the CH3CN species can be desorbed as a AcCN molecule (step (iv)). AcCN was proposed to be formed by the methylation of CN species on catalyst surface (step (iii) in Fig. 9). Accordingly, reducing the concentration of methyl group originated from methane should suppress AcCN formation. To support this claim, gaseous H2, which competes with methane for cyano-N and sp2-N species, was co-fed with methane and tested in the same condition. Fig. 10 a shows the value of the AcCN/(HCN+AcCN) ratio as a function of co-fed H2 concentration. The AcCN/(HCN+AcCN) ratio decreased sharply from 0.82 to 0.22 and then leveled off at approximately 0.1 with respect to the concentration of co-fed H2. That is, the higher the concentration of co-fed H2, the more cyano-N and sp2-N species were converted to form HCN instead of to be AcCN. This highlighted that the cyano-N and sp2-N species were key intermediates in AcCN formation. To further investigate the role of cyano-N and sp2-N species, an oxidative treatment of 5GaN/SiO2 was conducted at 550 °C in an air stream (see Fig. 10b). The initial AcCN productivity of oxidation-treated 5GaN/SiO2 was 248 µmol/gGa/min, which is lower than the value of its untreated form (326 µmol/gGa/min). The FTIR spectrum of oxidation-treated 5GaN/SiO2 (see Figure S7) exhibited lower intensities of the vibrational bands at 1500–1700 cm−1 and 2100–2350 cm−1 than those of its untreated counterpart, indicating the lower amount of surface cyano-N/sp2-N species of the oxidation-treated 5GaN/SiO2. The lower initial AcCN productivity of oxidation-treated 5GaN/SiO2 underlined the correlation between cyano-N/sp2-N species and AcCN productivity. Fig. 10c illustrates the H2-TPR profiles of 5GaN/SiO2. No H2 consumption or AcCN production was observed. That is, AcCN could not be generated without feeding methane. Furthermore, NH3 and HCN signals were observed at temperatures above 500 °C using 5GaN/SiO2, whereas these two products were absent when com-GaN was tested (Figure S8). This difference indicated that cyano-N/sp2-N species play a role in AcCN formation, whereas the N anions of wurtzite GaN do not. 3.4 Catalyst regeneration Coking is inevitable and cyano-N/sp2-N species is consumed in methane conversion. Hence, a calcination-nitridation-activation process of 5GaN/SiO2 was studied, and the activity evaluation is shown in Fig. 11 . After regeneration, the activity was partially rejuvenated. The initial methane conversion and AcCN productivity of regenerated 5GaN/SiO2 were 1.5% and 68.2 µmol/gGa/min, respectively, and were approximately 58% and 82% losses of the initial values of its fresh form. Another point worth mentioning is that the similar C2 productivities were observed for fresh and regenerated 5GaN/SiO2. The bulk and surface structures of regenerated 5GaN/SiO2 were analyzed by XAFS and FTIR, respectively. Figure S9 exhibited the Ga K-edge XANES spectrum of regenerated 5GaN/SiO2. The eight oscillation peaks and the absorption peak at 10,382.5 eV of GaN were identified for regenerated 5GaN/SiO2. This confirms that the GaN phase was preserved after regeneration. Figure S10 shows the FTIR spectra of fresh 5GaN/SiO2 and its spent, calcined, and regenerated forms. The band at 2100–2350 cm−1 was observed for each catalyst, but its amplitude was weaker for spent, calcined, or regenerated 5GaN/SiO2 than that of fresh 5GaN/SiO2. The band at 3000–3800 cm−1 was nearly vanished for spent 5GaN/SiO2 and reappeared for calcined and regenerated 5GaN/SiO2. The reappeared band at 3000–3800 cm−1 could be due to the removal of coke fouling. Therefore, we proposed that the partial recovery of AcCN productivity after catalyst regeneration was due to the burning of coke, which may bury some amorphous NC species. Worth noting that there are two new peaks at 3398 and 3448 cm−1 (NHx) in the spectrum of regenerated 5GaN/SiO2, suggesting the replenishment of N species after regeneration. The similar C2 productivities of fresh and regenerated 5GaN/SiO2 suggested that CC coupling was promoted by GaN phase [20] since both fresh and regenerated forms contained similar GaN structure. In brief, the cyano-N/sp2-N species could not be fully regenerated through ammonia nitridation. Catalyst regeneration by using other nitrogen sources (e.g., HCN) in the nitridation step is under investigation. 4 Conclusions This study sheds light on the anaerobic conversion of methane to AcCN over solid-state-pyrolysis-made GaN catalysts. The immobilized cyano-N and sp2-N species of the as-synthesized GaN catalysts could participate in AcCN formation. The productivities of AcCN, HCN, and C2 products increased, and the aromatics productivity decreased with a decrease of GaN crystallite size. Co-feeding H2 with methane suppressed AcCN productivity and was compensated by the enhanced yield of HCN due to the competitive interaction of H2 and methane with cyano-N and sp2-N species. Catalyst regeneration through a calcination-nitridation-activation procedure showed that the activity could be partially recovered. Designing cyano-N and sp2-N species-enriched GaN and developing an effective regeneration method shall improve AcCN yield and catalyst durability. coredata.dc:description: The anaerobic conversion of methane to acetonitrile (AcCN) using GaN catalysts synthesized through the solid-state pyrolysis of gallium nitrate hydrate and melamine was investigated. A series of GaN catalysts (unsupported GaN, 50 wt% GaN/SiO2, and 5 wt% GaN/SiO2) were prepared, and their physicochemical properties were analyzed. The as-synthesized GaN catalysts had higher porosities, lower crystallinities, and better activities than those of the commercial GaN. Among tested catalysts, 5 wt% GaN/SiO2 displayed the highest methane conversion rate and AcCN productivity at 700 °C. Residual carbonaceous and nitrogen species, such as sp2-N (N = C) and cyano-N (NC), are likely to participate in the transformation of methane to AcCN. The activity of post-reaction 5 wt% GaN/SiO2 could be partially rejuvenated by a calcination-nitridation-activation process.
coredata.dc:title: Anaerobic conversion of methane to acetonitrile over solid-state-pyrolysis-synthesized GaN catalysts
